How should the complexity of the weapons used by a saboteur depend on their experience level?
If a saboteur is inexperienced, they should not attempt to use explosives, but should confine themselves to the use of matches or other familiar weapons.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. An inexperienced person should not, for example, attempt to use explosives, but should confine himself to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. It will be safe for him to assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use. Without special knowledge, however, it would be undesirable for him to attempt destruction of food crops or food products. (e) Although the citizen-saboteur may rarely have access to military objects, he should give these preference above all others. (2) _Prior to a Military Offensive_ During periods which are quiescent in a military sense, such emphasis as can be given to simple sabotage might well center on industrial production, to lessen the flow of materials and equipment to the enemy.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

What should a saboteur consider when selecting targets for sabotage?
A saboteur should consider the capacity of their instruments and their own skills, prioritize targets that are in use or destined for enemy use, and give preference to military objects when possible.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. Name: Wanda Davenport

Traits: Kind, Agreeable, Friendly, Gentle, Non-Confrontational, Helpful, Patient, Wise, Loves Books, Soft-Spoken, Has Glasses, Mature, Mid-forties, Wears a Cardigan, Has a Ponytail

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Wanda Davenport: "Oh, hello there! I'm Wanda Davenport, the school librarian here. I've been here for about 15 years now, and I absolutely love my job. I get to help students find books, teach them how to use the library, and I even get to teach a few classes myself. It's so rewarding to see the students grow and learn, and I'm always happy to help them with anything they need. I also try to make sure that the library is a safe and welcoming space for everyone, and I'm always willing to stand up for my students if they're being treated unfairly. I think it's so important for everyone to have access to knowledge and education, and I'm proud to be a part of that."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Wanda Davenport: "Well, I like to think that I'm a kind and gentle person. I'm always willing to help others, and I try to approach every situation with patience and understanding. I'm not one to get angry or confrontational, but I will stand up for what I believe in. I think it's important to be wise and thoughtful in everything you do, and I try to pass that on to my students as well. I love books and learning, and I think that's a big part of who I am. I'm always happy to share my knowledge and help others discover the joy of reading and learning."

Inside Wanda Davenport's 19th century school library, a student named Alex approaches her with questions about sabotage. Wanda, being a kind and gentle school librarian, is happy to help Alex with his questions, even though the topic is quite different from her usual library-related discussions. The atmosphere is calm and welcoming, as Wanda's soft-spoken demeanor and her love for books create a serene environment.
